case_vignette: A 50-year-old female teacher presents to the clinic with complaints of discoloration of the skin around the right ankle accompanied by itching. She began noticing it a month ago and the pruritus worsened over time. She also has some pain and swelling of the region every night, especially on days when she teaches late into the evening. Her past medical history is significant for diabetes mellitus type 2, for which she takes metformin. She lives with her husband and takes oral contraceptive pills. On examination, the physician observes hyperpigmentation of the medial aspect of her right ankle. The skin is dry, scaly, and edematous along with some superficial varicosities. Dorsiflexion of the foot is extremely painful. Peripheral pulses are equally palpable on both lower limbs. There is a small 2 cm ulcer noted near the medial malleolus with thickened neighboring skin and indurated edges. Laboratory studies show D-dimer of 1,000 µg/L and HbA1c of 9%. Doppler ultrasound of the lower extremity reveals an intramural thrombus in the popliteal vein.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Cardiovascular System. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have discoloration of the skin around my right ankle that itches, and at night it swells and hurts, especially after a long day of teaching.
Do you have any known medical conditions, such as diabetes or cardiovascular issues?
Yes, I have type 2 diabetes.
Have you noticed any changes in color or temperature of the affected area on your ankle?
The skin around my right ankle has become darker.
Do you currently use any medications for your diabetes or any other conditions?
Yes, I take metformin for my diabetes.
Have you ever been diagnosed with peripheral artery disease or any circulation problems?
No, I haven't been diagnosed with those conditions.
Do you have any varicose veins or a history of deep vein thrombosis?
I have some superficial varicose veins around the affected area on my ankle.
Does the discoloration and swelling improve when you elevate your legs?
I haven't noticed if there's a difference when I elevate my legs.
Do you have a family history of cardiovascular disease or any circulation-related issues?
I don't have that information to share.
Has the skin around your ankle developed any open sores or ulcers?
Yes, there is a small ulcer near the inside bump of my ankle.
Final Diagnosis: Venous Stasis Ulcer

I'm a 50-year-old female.

No, I haven't injured my ankle or leg, and I haven't had similar issues in the past.
